course_outcomes: Understand the origin of soil and basic inter-relationships of soil components
Determine the index properties of soil and classify the soil based on the index properties
Understand the Soil-Water Interactions

syllabus.title: Introduction, Basic Definitions, Index Properties and Soil Classification
syllabus.topics: Scope of Geotechnical Engineering, origin and formation of soils. Phase diagrams, volumetric and weight relationships. Index Properties: Particle Size Distribution, Plasticity, Consistency Limits. Unified and Indian standard soil classification systems. Experiments: water content, specific gravity, grain size analysis, liquid and plastic limits, in-situ density.

syllabus.title: Soil Moisture, Permeability, and Effective Stress
syllabus.topics: Flow of water in soils, Darcy‘s law and its validity. Determination of coefficient of permeability. Seepage velocity and factors affecting permeability. Effective stress principle and its application under different loading conditions. Experiments: Constant head and Variable head permeability tests.

syllabus.title: Seepage and Compaction of Soils
syllabus.topics: Quick sand conditions, characteristics and uses of flow nets. Seepage through earth dams. Compaction: Standard and modified proctor tests, factors affecting compaction, and field compaction control. Experiments: Standard proctor compaction test.

syllabus.title: Consolidation and Shear Strength of Soils
syllabus.topics: Consolidation: Initial and secondary consolidation, Terazaghi's theory, consolidation test, and determination of coefficient of consolidation. Shear Strength: Mohr-coulomb theory, laboratory shear strength tests under different drainage conditions. Experiments: Direct shear test, Unconfined compression test, Vane shear test.

syllabus.title: Open Channel Flow: Uniform and Non-Uniform Flow

Laboratory tests: Determine Chezy‘s and Manning‘s coefficients, Reynolds's Number, and flow-rate using a V Notch.

syllabus.title: Gradually Varied Flow and Rapidly Varied Flow
syllabus.topics: Dynamic equation, types of surface profiles, and computation of surface profiles. Hydraulic jump, its elements, types, and applications. syllabus.title: Dimensional Analysis and Impact of Jets
syllabus.topics: Dimensional homogeneity, Rayleigh‘s method, Buckingham – Pi theorem, and similarities. Force exerted by fluid jet on stationary and moving plates. Angular momentum principle. Laboratory tests: Measurement of force due to impact of jet and determination of minor/major head losses in pipes.

syllabus.title: Hydraulic Turbines and Centrifugal Pumps
syllabus.topics: Classification of turbines (Impulse, Reaction). Pelton, Francis and Kaplan turbines. Draft tube theory and cavitation. Centrifugal Pumps: Types, working principle, manometric head, losses, efficiencies, and specific speed. Laboratory tests: Performance studies on centrifugal pump, reciprocating pump, and Francis turbine.

syllabus.title: Irrigation and Water Requirement of Crops
syllabus.topics: Definition, necessity, benefits, and ill-effects of irrigation. Methods of applying water to crops, including various flooding methods, furrow, sprinkler, and drip irrigation. Concepts of saturation capacity, field capacity, wilting point, duty, delta, and base period. Factors affecting duty and methods for its improvement. Assessment of irrigation water.

syllabus.title: Hydrology and Well Irrigation
syllabus.topics: Introduction to Engineering Hydrology, the hydrologic cycle, precipitation types, and computation of average rainfall. Runoff, factors affecting it, and its computation. Understanding hydrographs and unit hydrographs, including their application and limitations. Concepts of aquifers, aquicludes, aquifuge, and water table. Dupit’s theory for confined and unconfined aquifers and various well tests.

syllabus.title: Irrigation Channels and Waterlogging
syllabus.topics: Classification and alignment of canals. Silt theories by Kennedy and Lacey, including methods for channel design using these theories and their comparisons. Waterlogging causes, effects, and remedial measures. Types of canal lining and design of lined canals.

syllabus.title: Dams and Reservoir Planning
syllabus.topics: Classification of dams including gravity, arch, buttress, steel, timber, earth, and rock fill dams. Factors for selecting a dam site. Reservoir planning, site selection, storage zones, capacity, and yield. Use of mass inflow and demand curves to calculate reservoir capacity and safe yield, and understanding the life of a reservoir.

course_outcomes: evaluate the source of water for water supply scheme with reference to quantity and quality of water
apply and design the treatment units for purification of water and to understand the components of distribution systems and its analysis

syllabus.title: Introduction and Quantity & Quality of Water
syllabus.topics: Objectives of water supply systems, per capita consumption, design period, types of demands, and population prediction. Impurities in water, routine physical, chemical, and bacteriological tests, drinking water standards, and water-borne diseases. Lab tests include determination of pH, total solids, and alkalinity.

syllabus.title: Purification and Distribution of Water
syllabus.topics: Methods of water purification including plain sedimentation, coagulation, and filtration (slow sand and rapid sand filters). Disinfection methods like chlorination and miscellaneous treatments for hardness and de-fluoridation. Water distribution systems, layouts, reservoirs, and analysis methods. Basics of plumbing including pipes, fittings, and traps. Lab tests include determination of acidity, turbidity, and optimum coagulant dose.

syllabus.title: Sanitary Engineering and Primary Sewage Treatment
syllabus.topics: Introduction to sanitation, sewerage systems, and estimation of sanitary and storm water sewage quantities. Characteristics of sewage (physical, chemical, biological), decomposition cycles, BOD, and COD. Primary treatment units like screens, grit chambers, skimming tanks, sedimentation tanks, and septic tanks. Lab tests include determination of hardness, chloride, and sulphate content.

syllabus.title: Secondary Treatment and Disposal of Sewage
syllabus.topics: Secondary treatment methods including trickling filters and the activated sludge process, covering principles, operation, and common issues like sludge bulking. Methods of sewage disposal such as disposal by dilution, self-purification process in rivers, oxygen sag, and disposal by irrigation. Lab tests include determination of dissolved oxygen (DO), biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), and chemical oxygen demand (COD).
